title: PART A: THESIS/CLAIM
stimulusHtml: To earn this point, the thesis must make a claim that responds to the prompt, rather than restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.
descriptions: The response does not respond to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

The response responds to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning about the extent to which United States foreign policy in the period 1970 to 1990 contributed to the end of the Cold War. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following.

· “The driving force leading to the end of the Cold War was the United State foreign policy combining a buildup of conventional and nuclear weaponry with active diplomacy abroad.”

· “Although the United States foreign policy played an important role in the end of the Cold War, the most important reason for this development was the internal collapse of the Soviet Union and its empire in Eastern Europe.”

title: PART B: CONTEXTUALIZATION
stimulusHtml:
To earn this point, the response must describe broader historical events, developments, or processes that occur before, during, or continue after the time frame of the question that are relevant to the topic of the prompt. To earn this point, the context provided must be more than a phrase or a reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.
descriptions: The response does not describe a broader historical context relevant to the extent to which United States foreign policy in the period 1970 to 1990 contributed to the end of the Cold War.

The response describes a broader historical context relevant to the extent to which United States foreign policy in the period 1970 to 1990 contributed to the end of the Cold War.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples of context might include the following, with appropriate elaboration:

· The United States pursued a policy of containing the spread of communism throughout most of the Cold War, dating from approximately 1945.

· United States conflicts in Vietnam and Southeast Asia partly undermined United States standing internationally.

· Anti-communism was a key element of the new conservatism that helped increase the political power of the Republican Party from the 1960s to the 1980s.

· The United States and the Soviet Union engaged in an international rivalry throughout the period after the Second World War. This rivalry included athletic contests, the space race, and efforts to win the hearts and minds of people throughout the world.

· The Richard Nixon administration sought to create a policy of détente, or mutual coexistence, with the Soviet Union and China in the early 1970s.

· In the 1980s, the United States economy recovered from a recession and many people enjoyed financial prosperity, while the Soviet economy experienced slow growth and shortages of goods.

title: PART C1: EVIDENCE – USES THE CONTENT OF THE DOCUMENTS
stimulusHtml: To earn one point, the response must accurately describe—rather than simply quote—the content from at least three of the documents.
descriptions: The response does not use the content of at least three documents to address the topic of the prompt.
The response uses the content of at least three documents to address the topic of the prompt. Must accurately describe—rather than simply quote—the content from at least three documents.

title: PART C2: SUPPORTS AN ARGUMENT USING DOCUMENTS
stimulusHtml: To earn this point, the response must accurately describe—rather than simply quote—the content from at least four documents. In addition, the response must use the content of the documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.
descriptions: The response does not use at least four documents to support an argument in response to the prompt.
The response supports an argument in response to the prompt using at least four documents.

title: PART C3: EVIDENCE – EVIDENCE BEYOND THE DOCUMENTS
stimulusHtml:
To earn this point, the response must describe the evidence and must use more than a phrase or reference. This additional piece of evidence must be different from the evidence used to earn the point for contextualization. The point for evidence beyond the documents may be awarded for evidence that appears in any part of the response.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.
descriptions: The response does not use at least one additional piece of the specific historical evidence (beyond that found in the documents) relevant to an argument about the prompt.

The response uses at least one additional piece of the specific historical evidence (beyond that found in the documents) relevant to an argument about the prompt.

· This additional piece of evidence must be different from the evidence used to earn the point for contextualization. Typically, statements credited as contextualization will be more general statements that place an argument or a significant portion of it in a broader context.

· Statements credited as supporting evidence beyond the documents will typically be more specific details that function as support for a particular point made in an argument, analogous to the function of evidence drawn from the documents.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Evidence beyond the documents might include the following, with appropriate elaboration:

· Détente

· George H. W. Bush

· Glasnost

· Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT)

· Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty

· Pope John Paul II

· Strategic Arms Reduction Talks (START)

· Strategic Defense Initiative (SDI)

· Velvet Revolution in Czechoslovakia

· Lech Wałesa, Solidarity in Poland

· Boris Yeltsin

· 1980 Summer Olympics; United States boycott

Some examples that would earn credit include:

· “The Reagan administration used the Strategic Arms Reduction Talks to try to both reduce the proliferation of nuclear weapons and achieve a tactical advantage over the Soviet Union.”

· “A series of revolutions in Eastern Europe in the late 1980s saw countries like Czechoslovakia, Hungary, and Poland seek to break away from Soviet dominance, which undermined the power of the Soviet Union and contributed to the end of the Cold War”

title: PART D1: ANALYSIS AND REASONING – SOURCING
stimulusHtml: To earn this point, the response must explain how or why (rather than simply identifying) the document’s point of view, purpose, historical situation, or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for each of the two documents sourced.
descriptions: The response does not explain how or why the document’s point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two documents.
The response explains how or why the documents’ point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument about the prompt for at least two of the documents.

title: PART D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING – COMPLEXITY
stimulusHtml:
To earn this point, the response must demonstrate a complex understanding.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

· Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

· Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

· Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

· Effectively using six documents to support an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

· Explaining how the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of at least four documents supports an argument that responds to the prompt; OR

· Using documents and evidence beyond the documents effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.
descriptions: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the historical development that is the focus of the prompt.

The response demonstrates a complex understanding of the historical development that is the focus of the prompt, through sophisticated argumentation and/or effective use of evidence.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

· Explaining a nuance by exploring different ways (e.g., through economic pressure, diplomacy, and military actions) in which United States foreign policy contributed to the end of the Cold War

· Explaining similarities and differences between the United States foreign policies in different parts of the world, such as Latin America, Eastern Europe, and Southeast Asia, in relation to the end of the Cold War

· Explaining connections to other time periods such as the way that United States foreign policy contributed to the end of the First World War

· Confirming the validity of the response’s argument about the United States expanding role in the world by explaining how different documents corroborate the argument in spite of differing perspectives among the authors (for example, explaining how Jimmy Carter’s call for human rights as a driving element in United States foreign policy and Ronald Reagan’s emphasis on deterrence were both part of a consistent United States foreign policy, in spite of the political differences between the two presidents)

· Qualifying or modifying an argument by considering evidence that shows the contradictions in the United States role in the world at the same time it was supporting authoritarian governments in Central America

· Assessing the relative importance of United States foreign policy throughout the response, not simply stating its importance
